titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers
1959 - 2005
MSS 321
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Colin Torre, 2012.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-03-26T17:44-0400

did.unittitle: John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers

physdesc.extent: (3 records cartons, 4 flat boxes, 2 manuscript cases, 2 oversize boxes)

did.abstract: John Vaccaro is an actor and theatrical director who became a primary figure of the Off-Off Broadway and gay theater communities in New York City. The John Vaccaro Papers preserve the items related to Vaccaro’s theatrical productions, including scripts, correspondence, photographs, posters and critical notices.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival collections. Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu or call 212 998 2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers; MSS 321; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into 3 series. Oversize materials are listed at the end of the finding aid.

Series I: Projects includes the work of John Vaccaro and others, and is organized alphabetically by project title. Folders contain press clippings, screenplays, and ephemera generally related to the titular project.
Series II: Posters Ephemera includes posters and publicity material related to Vaccaro's theatrical productions.

Series III: Photographs contains photographs, contact sheets, negatives, and slides pertaining to Vaccaro's productions and personal collection. There is little order to the photographs, and most are unidentified.
Oversize Series I: Projects contains oversize material related to theatrical productions. Folders are arranged alphabetically.
Oversize Series II: Posters includes posters and publicity material related to Vaccaro's theatrical productions.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John Vaccaro was born in Steubenville, Ohio on December 6, 1929. After serving in the U.S. Navy from 1951-1955, and receiving a B.A. in English from Ohio State University in 1961, he moved to New York City and became involved in the underground art and film community of the early sixties. After acting in Jack Smith's Normal Love and Flaming Creatures, and performing in the "Happenings" of Robert Whitman and Walter DeMaria, Vaccaro founded the Play-House of the Ridiculous in the summer of 1965. Early collaborators and playwrights in this community included Ronald Tavel, Charles Ludlam and Kenneth Bernard. In 1967, during preparatory work for a production of Ludlam's play Conquest of the Universe, or When Queens Collide Vaccaro and Ludlam came to a disagreement and split into competing companies (Vaccaro retained the Play-House of the Ridiculous; Ludlam founded the Ridiculous Theatrical Company).

Vaccaro's productions were staged at the Coda Gallery, La Mama ETC, the Gotham Art Theater, Max's Kansas City, The American Place Theater, and other Off-Broadway and Off-Off-Broadway venues in New York. In 1970 Vaccaro received a special citation OBIE award. While sometimes performing in and writing the music for his own productions, Vaccaro took his companies on tours of Europe throughout the 1970s and served as director of the Native American Theatrical Ensemble. His theatrical influences include Alfred Jarry, Amiri Baraka, Eugene Ionesco, Charlie Chaplin, Antonin Artaud, and Jack Smith. In addition to the non-professional actors often employed in his productions, Vaccaro is associated with a variety of figures from the New York art and theater worlds, including Taylor Mead, Beverly Grant, Mary Woronov, Rene Ricard, Rosalyn Drexler, Ultra Violet, and Richard Weinstock. Vaccaro has lectured at a number universities and workshops, and has directed performances of his productions for the BBC and Dutch television.
"Life of Juanita Castro" by Ronald Tavel (1965)
"The Life of Lady Godiva" by Ronald Tavel (1966)
"Screen Test"/"Indira Gandhi's Daring Device" both by Ronald Tavel (1966)
"Conquest of the Universe" by Charles Ludlam (1967)
"Monkeys of the Organ Grinder" by Kenneth Bernard (1969)
"Heaven Grand In Amber Orbit" by Jackie Curtis (1969)
"Son of Cock Strong" by Tom Murrin (1970)
"Life of Lady Godiva" by Ronald Tavel (1971)
"The Life of Juanita Castro" by Ronald Tavel (1971)
"Persia, A Desert Cheapie" by Bernard Roth & Vaccaro (1972)
"Elegy for a Down Queen" by Leslie Lee (1973)
"The Magic Show of Dr. Magico" by Kenneth Bernard (1973-1974)
"Workshop of Y.M.C.A." by Gerome Ragni & James Rado (1975-1976)
"The Sixty Minute Queer Show" by Kenneth Bernard (1977)
"The Book of Etiquette" by William M. Hoffman (1979)
"A Midsummer Night's Dream" by William Shakespeare (1980)
"La Fin du Cirque" by Kenneth Bernard (1984)
"The Heart That Eats Itself" by Rosalyn Drexler (1987)

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers were donated to the Fales Library by John Vaccaro in 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The John Vaccaro and the Play-House of the Ridiculous Papers contain materials that document Vaccaro's professional theatrical career, ranging from the early 1960s through 2005. The collection preserves Vaccaro's primarily collaborative work, including scripts, notebooks, articles, essays, and correspondence that date back to his early career as an actor in the emerging world of Off-Off Broadway theater in New York. Elements include source material for his productions as well as promotional material in the form of ephemera, flyers, festival programs, posters and postcards. This body of components also includes the work of collaborating playwrights, and material related to the theatrical and Greenwich Village communities of the 1960s, 70s and 80s. In addition, this collection includes professional and personal correspondence, production and personal photography, original illustrations, and a scrapbook.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Most of the people and plays in the photographs in the collection are unidentified at this time, and remain roughly in the order they were in when donated by Vaccaro.
